title: Matt Bowen predicts Cowboys win
text:
Weather: Cairns 20 °C - 28 °C . Shower or two. Sport Cowboys and Maroons legend Matt Bowen on impending retirement and NRL grand final by: What are these? RETIRING GREAT: Former North Queensland Cowboys fullback Matt Bowen has tipped his old club to win this weekend’s grand final against the Brisbane Broncos. PICTURE: JAKE NOWAKOWSKI Source: News Limited 
TWO decades on from when Matt Bowen first played football as a schoolboy at Ingham, the star fullback and North Queensland Cowboys legend is two grand finals away from retirement. 
Bowen, a Cairns-born former Maroon and Kangaroo, has tipped his old club to win by six points in tomorrow’s historic NRL premiership decider. 
He will watch the game from his home in Greater Manchester and thinks the Cowboys will need to fire in order to beat the Brisbane Broncos. 
But the 33-year-old, who was raised in Hope Vale and played 270 games for North Queensland, has a grand final of his own next weekend in the English Super League. 
The Cairns Post spoke with Bowen the morning before his team, the Wigan Warriors, smashed their way past the Huddersfield Giants. 
Bowen and the Warriors will contest the 2015 Super League premiership next Saturday at Manchester’s Old Trafford stadium. 
Reflecting on his unsuccessful NRL premiership bid in 2005, Bowen said a more experienced and disciplined Cowboys side would learn from their previous errors. STILL GOT IT: Matt Bowen in action for the Wigan Warriors. PICTURE: Gareth COPLEY/GETTY Source: Getty Images 
“It’s one of the greatest honours to play in a grand final, but unfortunately we lost,” he said. 
“Back then, we were a pretty young side and we could have done a few things differently, but it’s an exciting week. 
“You can’t wait for the game, you want to train well and do all the little things right. 
“They’ve been playing well all year … I’m sure they’ll be up for it this weekend.” 
Bowen played his whole 12-year NRL career with the Cowboys. 
He made 10 appearances for Queensland in State of Origin, played one Test for Australia, and was awarded a Dally M medal for fullback of the year in 2007. 
He left for England after the 2013 season but said he still kept in touch with his old teammates. 
“I’ve been speaking to Ray Thompson and Johnno (Thurston) this week,” Bowen said. 
“He’s (Thurston) pretty excited and he’s got all the individual medals at the moment, but he obviously wants the premiership for the Cowboys. 
“A few of the boys that are in key positions have been playing well – Johnno, Matty Scott’s playing well, big Jase (Jason Taumalolo). 
“You need them all to fire.” 
Bowen said rugby league in the United Kingdom was “a bit faster” but the game in Australia was “more physical”. 
“It’s a bit different – for starters it’s cold,” he said. 
He will be returning home at the end of this year and starting a post-playing career role in community development for the Cowboys.
